reviewText: Great indie game, the focus is clearly not the best graphics or mechanics in the world (however the game does a decent job at those), the focus is rather the lesson learned from it, and serves as a tool to visualize how micro-transactions ruin gameplay.\nSurely not a $60 game, however it is a steal at it's current sale price of $3.99.

reviewText:
Played the game to completion. I was NOT amused with the end statement and secret.

Pay to Enjoy yourself.

The END

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

I didn't like it. I played it on hard mode. (Least money spent) You're not supposed to enjoy it.

Therefore:

It did its job. And that is what my recommendation is based on.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The only reason I recommend this is that there are some idiots who don't understand the concepts provided by the game.

So, go on, play this textbook and repeat your heart out.

reviewText: Pay2Win: The Tricks Exposed is a bitter, cynical, and angry game. It strips away the fluff from games and reveals the hollow skeleton beneath. As P2W reveals these tactics in a clinical way, you can't help but notice parallels with some of your favorite games, whether they're Pay 2 Win" or not. Hopefully
date: this will make you contemplate how you spend your money and
hoursPlayed: your time.\n\nThere are a lot of great
voteText: laugh-out-loud moments where the game finds new ways to extract your cash and make you feel like you're getting a good deal out of it. The combat is mindless. The rewards are meaningless. The grind is endless.\n\nAn empty world
votesHelpful: and an addictive but ultimately imagined sense of progression are all that await you in the hours you will spend completing it. As a nihilistic statement about gaming
votesFunny: a dadaistic masterpiece. I wholeheartedly recommend you experience it.\n\nHowever
commentsCount: I do not recommend you experience it via purchasing and playing through the game
column16: because doing so is nearly impossible. Exactly why this is would be a spoiler and too nit-picky to get into
column17: but suffice to say this game is better experienced via a well-edited Let's Play video* rather than actually enduring it yourself. Like an Andy Kaufman performance
column18:
it's more enjoyable to hear about afterwards than to actually attend.


* I recommend this video
column19: which shows all the game's content within the span of about an hour. Muting the audio to block out the annoying guy is optional. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C4XZwfV2lT8"

reviewText:
It's really is an educational software of some kind rather than a game. If you can force yourself through neverending tedious quests, go for it. Even though NPCs clearly say that their quests are BS, you still can get that sense of accomplishment while doing them and feel your place in the game world. It's Human Psychology 101.

To be honest, I didn't complete it (Steam shows I played for 0.6 hours). But I can freely recommend it to anyone who wants to experience what F2P MMOs are about. What, you were waiting for fun? Grind, pay, grind. Click, click, click.

Still, there's no options whatsoever. It wouldn't be that much of a problem, but there's something wrong with the camera movement so I can't play the game for too long (getting motion sickness or something like that). It can be just me, it can be other people as well.

p.s. Never forget that holding Alt enables mouse cursor and allows you to add money. If I remember correctly, the game never tolds you that.

Review key provided by the developer.

Sasha Darko for Game Obscura

reviewText: Remember a few years ago, back when World of Warcraft was at its player-base peak of about 12 million players?  Back then there would be new MMORPGs that came out fairly regularly, nearly a new one every month.  Each of them claimed to be the WoW Killer"
date: that they were going to force players off of WoW servers by enticing them to play something else.  None of those games ever succeeded.\n\n*This* game does.  This $4.99 near joke of a game
recommended: designed purely to make a point about anti-fun... *this* is the WoW Killer.  After playing this for less than two hours
hoursPlayed: I doubt I'll ever log onto WoW again.  There are too many things in the world that generate true fun
voteText: so I'm not going to dump my time
votesHelpful: and MONEY into something that doesn't deserve any of those things.  This is a lesson I had already learned
votesTotal: but this game served to remind me.\n\nAlso
votesFunny: for a game that was designed to make people hate it
commentsCount: this was surprisingly well put together.  It managed to avoid all the terrible glitches that plague many of the low budget crap games on Steam.  I get the feeling that if this dev wanted to make a *fun* game
column16: then it would be pretty great.\n\nFinal verdict:  I got this in a bundle
column17: so it was totally worth the 58 cents
column18: if for no other reason than to remind me not to play MMORPGs.  If you have a friend or family member who is addicted to an MMORPG
column19: then this might be able to break them of it... maybe."

reviewText:
So its not common that i write reviews at all. But i do so when i find a game that has an interesting or fun experience. This is not really a funny game but its more of a game that teaches you how big companies are forcing you to buy in game currency for certain things. I know my self i have many times found a fun looking game that i would like to continue in but ive always stopped myself when all those P2W comes up. Sadly but true almost  every game has some P2W content. Not that extreme that you HAVE to spend but it would surely make it more easy and enyojable. Mainly i play League of Legends. You can earn yourself all the characters in the game OR you could buy them with in game currency that cost real money ofcourse. But ive never stopped playing LoL because of that. I mean the developers need to earn money in some way and i can understand that. But now when it comes to the part that i cant continue playing if i dont pay. Thats just terrible. I will talk about this game now and how i felt like playing it.

+ Pros
+Teaches us in a really good way how big companies uses different bussiness models to force" us into buying virtual currency.
+ The game is fun in some parts.
+ Got some okay soundtrack but gets tiresome. (Its like 2 different songs)

- Cons
- Could really get annoying and boring sometimes. The feeling when your doing the same thing over and over again was really not that great.
- The developer could have made it that way so it was more fun and enjoyable to play AND we could learn at the same time. I would have loved the game so more.
- Really NOT replayable. Just no. The game itself its pretty boring and i see no meaning of replaying it.

I would recommend most people to try this out. You could think for yourself
date: what am i putting my money on and is it really worth it? I have spent SO MUCH on my favourite games out there you guys dont even know. But as a gamer in my heart it was all worth it. // He-_-Pole"
helpfulPercent: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I love the lesson that this game tries to teach players about the methods Pay-2-Win games use to steal your money.  Unfortunately, I didn't have the endurance to beat the game myself (the part where the game wants you to upgrade all of your armor is incredibly tedious), but I did watch the rest of the game on youtube, and I got pretty much the same thing out of it.  If you want to learn the methods that Pay-2-Win games use to get your hard-earned dough, and don't mind spending a while trying to grind the part where your have to upgrade your items, then this game is for you.

reviewText: This game is ok, the idea of the game being funny and ingenious and the gameplay and quest rather comedic. One thing I have to complain about is the fact that auto-save does not work and there is no other way to save. Another thing is the reinforcement. The reinforcement of the rental items is quite absurd and has the odds against you greatly. I bought all the rental items and 66 reinforcement stones, 63 reinforcement chance up 50%, and 55 reinforcement saftey scrolls(eliminates the item from breaking if the reinforcement is a failure) and i ended up with nothing leveled up except for the rental sword which grew to level 7. I am very disappointed about these two things because this is a very fun game. Please either fix or make these two things easier to accomplish in a future update.

reviewText:
I do not recommend this game with a caveat.

This game is not for a savy player it would seem. It is not an exploration of the strangenesses of the concept a la DLC Quest. It is more intended as an educational tool which I would say would best serve teenagers or possibly a younger audience.

As an adult who loves games and has considered this type of thing, there does not seem to be anything new here. I did grin at the humor of much of the text and the sort of semi-intentional poor craftsmanship of the game.

I just can't recommend this game, and I think it is because I am not sure who the audience should be. I want to say it is for the more naive, but the early introduction and some of the more blatant jokes about how bad games like this can get (the ones that tell you they are bad) seem like they would ruin the effect. I want to say it is for the audience that finds this topic interesting, but I do not think you would find anything new here, just cyinical jokes of the state of some of the gaming industry which, while entertaining, do not make up for the money _and_ time invested in getting to them.

I will pick this back up, as it seems there may be more under the surface that I didn't hit in the first 17 minutes of gameplay. But right now initial impressions point to no.

reviewText: So, uh. This is quite accurate to what it says it's trying to be, and well done in several ways. Your reward" for completing quests is a brief explanation of one concept or trick employed by those shady developers to extract a gazillion dollars from you.\n\nI quit after about 15 minutes. reviewText:
It's pretty much exactly as it says on the tin.
This game basically holds your hand while hammering in your head how free-to-play game developers try to trick you into paying as much money as possible.
However, it's far more ham-fisted in Pay2Win, and it's just not fun, nor all that educational. (As all of it is pretty much common sense).
The real kicker is that the whole thing costs $5.
Save your money and just use common sense, and spare yourself the waste of time and money.
